articles.headline: Buddhists Go to Battle: When Nationalism Overrides Pacifism
articles.snippet: A call to arms for Sri Lankan monks. Ethnic cleansing of the Rohingya in Myanmar. A Buddhist faith known for pacifism is taking its place in a new age of nationalism.
articles.abstract: A call to arms for Sri Lankan monks. Ethnic cleansing of the Rohingya in Myanmar. A Buddhist faith known for pacifism is taking its place in a new age of nationalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: GINTOTA, Sri Lanka — The Buddhist abbot was sitting cross-legged in his monastery, fulminating against the evils of Islam, when the petrol bomb exploded within earshot.

articles.headline: As Cameras Track Detroit’s Residents, a Debate Ensues Over Racial Bias
articles.snippet: Studies have shown that facial recognition software can return more false matches for African-Americans than for white people, a sign of what experts call “algorithmic bias.”
articles.abstract: Studies have shown that facial recognition software can return more false matches for African-Americans than for white people, a sign of what experts call “algorithmic bias.”
articles.lead_paragraph: [For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

articles.headline: Leaked British Cables Critical of Trump Lead to Diplomatic Uproar
articles.snippet: President Trump’s statement came close to declaring Kim Darroch, the ambassador, persona non grata — an extraordinary breach between the United States and one of its closest allies.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s statement came close to declaring Kim Darroch, the ambassador, persona non grata — an extraordinary breach between the United States and one of its closest allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump celebrates his bond with Queen Elizabeth II. He is less charitable about those who serve her.

articles.headline: Global Recession Risks Are Up, and Central Banks Aren’t Ready
articles.snippet: The world’s monetary authorities have limited policy space, and it’s unclear whether their backup plans will suffice to bolster growth and inflation.
articles.abstract: The world’s monetary authorities have limited policy space, and it’s unclear whether their backup plans will suffice to bolster growth and inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Central bankers have a favorite mantra: Patch the roof while the sun is shining.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jack Ewing and Ben Dooley

articles.headline: For France’s Jobless, Macron Aims to ‘Make Work Pay’
articles.snippet: President Emmanuel Macron’s next chapter in altering the national economy is tightening jobless benefits to get the unemployed back to work faster.
articles.abstract: President Emmanuel Macron’s next chapter in altering the national economy is tightening jobless benefits to get the unemployed back to work faster.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Franck Provost, a high-profile coiffeur with more than 500 hair salons across France, needed to do some hiring last fall in the central Loire region. But when an associate reached out to 130 unemployed stylists, he said, only two replied.

articles.headline: Ross Perot, Brash Texas Billionaire Who Ran for President, Dies at 89
articles.snippet: Mr. Perot made a fortune in computer services, mounted bizarre paramilitary missions in Asia and was a strong third-party hopeful in the 1990s.
articles.abstract: Mr. Perot made a fortune in computer services, mounted bizarre paramilitary missions in Asia and was a strong third-party hopeful in the 1990s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ross Perot, the wiry Texas gadfly who made a fortune in computer services, amazed the nation with audacious paramilitary missions to Vietnam and Iran, and ran for president in 1992 and 1996 with populist talk of restoring Norman Rockwell’s America, died on Tuesday at his home in Dallas. He was 89.

articles.headline: Twitter Backs Off Broad Limits on ‘Dehumanizing’ Speech
articles.snippet: After a year of debate and criticism, an effort to add to a policy on banned speech led to a narrower restriction that applies only when religious groups are targeted.
articles.abstract: After a year of debate and criticism, an effort to add to a policy on banned speech led to a narrower restriction that applies only when religious groups are targeted.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last August, Twitter’s top executives gathered at the company’s headquarters to discuss how to make the site safer for its users. Two attendees proposed banning all speech that could be considered “dehumanizing.” For an example of what they meant, they showed a sample post that featured the words President Trump used to  compare certain nations to excrement.

articles.headline: Tensions Between Pelosi and Progressive Democrats of ‘the Squad’ Burst Into Flame
articles.snippet: Tensions between Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and her “squad” have burst into the open, testing House Democratic unity.
articles.abstract: Tensions between Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and her “squad” have burst into the open, testing House Democratic unity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi said they have no following in Congress. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York shot back that she and three of her fellow liberal freshmen, darlings of the left known collectively as “the squad,” are wielding the real power in the party.

articles.headline: Trump Can’t Block Critics From His Twitter Account, Appeals Court Rules
articles.snippet: The decision may have broader implications for how the First Amendment applies to officials’ accounts in the social-media era.
articles.abstract: The decision may have broader implications for how the First Amendment applies to officials’ accounts in the social-media era.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has been violating the Constitution by blocking people from following his Twitter account because they criticized or mocked him, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday. The ruling could have broader implications for how the First Amendment applies to the social-media era.

articles.headline: A Billionaire’s Fall Spotlights Child Sexual Abuse in China
articles.snippet: The police detained Wang Zhenhua for unspecified “personal reasons,” but officials are calling for an investigation after reports accused him of molestation.
articles.abstract: The police detained Wang Zhenhua for unspecified “personal reasons,” but officials are calling for an investigation after reports accused him of molestation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The detention of a billionaire Shanghai real estate developer in a case linked by Communist Party officials to the alleged sexual molestation of a 9-year-old girl has triggered a national bout of soul searching in China, where such crimes are rapidly moving toward the top of law enforcement priorities.
articles.byline: By Ailin Tang and Keith Bradsher
